concern:
For the past year and half, my college have has been difficult.  I often worked 40-50 hour weeks and when I got home had no motivation to study. Not to say I didn't I passed at least one class per semester. Yet my gpa was 0.22 something incredibly low 

A year and half later and now I'm on academic suspension. I feel sick from this revelation and I don't know why.

Any advice or words of wisdom because I was told to never stop but I can progress with this suspension in my way

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our counseling session today! I'm here to listen and support you, so please feel free to share whatever thoughts or concerns you have on your mind. Take your time, and let's work through this together. ðŸ˜Š
Hey, thanks for being here. Iâ€™m just really overwhelmed with this academic suspension and feeling pretty lost about what to do next.

That must be a really tough place to be in, feeling overwhelmed and unsure of what to do next. It takes a lot of courage to share this, and I'm here to listen and support you. Can you tell me more about what's been going on with your academic suspension?
Hey, yeah, itâ€™s been a rough ride, and Iâ€™m just kinda reeling from the whole suspension thing. I guess Iâ€™m trying to figure out how I even got here and what steps I can take to bounce back.

It sounds like you're feeling a mix of confusion and frustration, trying to make sense of how things got to this point. It's understandable that you'd want to figure out how to bounce back from this setback. I'm here to help you navigate these feelings and work through the steps that might be helpful for you.
Thanks for understanding where Iâ€™m at right now. I just feel like Iâ€™ve hit a wall and donâ€™t even know where to start climbing over it.

It's completely understandable to feel like you've hit a wall, and I can imagine how frustrating and overwhelming that must be. It's important to remember that setbacks like this are a part of life, and it's okay to take your time to process and figure out the next steps. I'm here to support you, and we can take things one step at a time together.
Hey, I really appreciate that, knowing I donâ€™t have to rush through this mess. I guess Iâ€™m just worried about how to even begin picking up the pieces, ya know?

I hear you, it can feel really daunting to start picking up the pieces when things seem so overwhelming. Let's take a step back and try to focus on one small step at a time. Can you tell me about one thing you feel might be a good place to start?

Honestly, Iâ€™m not even sure where to start, it all feels like such a mess. Maybe just figuring out what went wrong with my study habits or time management could be a first step, but I donâ€™t know how to dig into that without feeling worse about myself.
It's okay to take your time and figure things out at your own pace. What if we started by simply reflecting on how your study habits and time management have been impacting your goals lately?
Yeah, I think reflecting on that could help, even if itâ€™s hard to look at. I just donâ€™t want to end up feeling more stuck or beating myself up over past mistakes, ya know?

I hear you, and it's completely understandable to want to avoid feeling stuck or beating yourself up. Let's focus on understanding the impact of your study habits and time management in a way that feels manageable and non-judgmental. Can you tell me more about how you think your current habits might be affecting your progress toward your goals?

Yeah, I can try to break it down, even if itâ€™s kinda tough to think about. I guess Iâ€™ve been so overwhelmed with long work hours that I just crash when I get home, and studying feels like the last thing I can handle, so I keep putting it off.

I hear you. It sounds like you're caught in a cycle where work and exhaustion are making it hard to make progress on your goals. What if we focused on how making even small changes to your study habits and time management might help break this cycle and create more balance in your life?

Yeah, Iâ€™m open to trying small changes, â€˜cause right now it feels like Iâ€™m just spinning my wheels. I just donâ€™t know where to even start with balancing everything without feeling like Iâ€™m dropping the ball somewhere else.

That makes sense. It can be overwhelming to balance everything, especially when you're already feeling exhausted. What if we explored some small, realistic adjustments to your routine that could create a bit more space for studying without adding to your stress? Maybe even one or two things that feel doable right now?

Yeah, Iâ€™d be down to look at some small tweaks to my routine, â€˜cause I really need something that doesnâ€™t feel like a huge burden. Like, if we can figure out just a couple things I can actually stick to, thatâ€™d be a start, ya know?

Alright, let's start with what feels manageable. What if we look at your current routine and find a couple of small adjustments that could create some space for studying without adding to your stress? Maybe something like carving out a specific time slot each day, or adjusting your work hours slightly to allow for some study time?
Yeah, that sounds doable, like maybe finding a specific time each day could help me get into a rhythm. Iâ€™m just worried Iâ€™ll still feel too drained after work to actually stick with it, ya know?

Itâ€™s understandable that feeling drained after work could make sticking to a new routine challenging. What if we considered how you might recharge a bit before diving into studying, like taking a short walk, listening to music, or even just having a cup of tea? Maybe we could also look at your work schedule and see if thereâ€™s a way to adjust your hours slightly to give you some more energy for studying?

Yeah, I like the idea of recharging a bit before jumping into studying, like maybe a quick walk or just chilling with some music could help reset my head. Iâ€™m not sure about adjusting work hours yet, thoughâ€”my scheduleâ€™s pretty locked in, but Iâ€™m open to brainstorming ways to make it work.

Great! It sounds like taking a moment to recharge could make a big difference. What if we focused on building a short, daily routine that includes both your recharging activity and a manageable study session? Maybe we could start with just one or two days a week, to see what works best for you?

Yeah, starting with just one or two days a week sounds way less intimidating, and I think I could handle that without feeling overwhelmed. Iâ€™m cool with trying a short routine that mixes in some recharging and studyingâ€”letâ€™s see how it goes, ya know?

therapist: Iâ€™m glad youâ€™re open to giving this a try. Letâ€™s check in next session to see how itâ€™s working and tweak anything if neededâ€”does that sound good to you?

client: Yeah, that sounds perfect. Iâ€™ll keep track of how it feels and let you know next time.
